SECRET.
No. 0.A.B./87.
General Headquarters,
British Armies in France.
20th January, 1918.
Chief of the Imperial General Staff.
I beg to forward herewith reports received from the G.O.C., R.F.C, on the Bombing Raids carried out by the Ochey Squadrons on the night of the 16th/17th January, 1918.
(Sd.) K. Ingram,
B.G.
for Field-Marshal Commanding-in-Chief,
British Armies in France. DETAILED REPORT ON BOMB RAID CARRIED OUT ON NIGHT 16th/17th January, 1918.At 12*5 aam. 6 machines of No. 100 Squadron left to attack the Factory and Railway Junction at Diedenhofen.The weather had been bad up till then and although there was no moon the night now appeared to be clear. However, on reaching the lines, they found the weather was worse, and visibility almost impossible. 4 machines returned. The remaining 2 crossed the lines. Weather conditions rapidly deteriorated and one machine dropped 1 - 230 lb. and 2 - 25, lb, bombs on the large Railway Sidings at Bernsdorf. The results were obscured due to the mist. 100 rounds were fired at lights on the Railway, The other machine dropped 1 - 230 lb. and 1-25 lb, bombs on the Railwayj and 1 - 25 lb. bomb on searchlight near Vigny, but the results were again obscured.lights were seen and machines were practically unmolested. No traffic or lighted Aerodromes were visible.Total amount of bombs dropped 560 lbs., and 100 rounds fired.A,A. Deiences were dormant.Very few search-In the Field. 17th Jan. 1918.(Sd.) G.E.A. Baldwin, Major. Commanding 41st Wing, Royal Flying Corps.
